title: WTF Are these Taliyah Nerfs????
body:
Holllyyy crap. They're really gutting her now boys.

•Mana growth lowered to 50 from 60
•Base Mana regen lowered to 1.2 from 1.4
•Mana regen growth lowered to .16 from .17
•Threaded Volley (Q) no longer deals 50% extra damage to minions.
Unraveled Earth (E) trap damage lowered to 80/100/120/140/160 from 80/105/130/155/180

This is, honestly, one of the biggest nerfs since Kalista or Kindred. It's a shame too, because she didn't get that much time to shine. So, as you can expect now, she will be ABSOLUTE garbage in soloq and probably not pickable in LCS or other championships either. The reason why is because now she has less pushing power (A SUBSTANTIAL AMOUNT LESS AT THAT), less damage for poking people in lane, a worse laning phase overall due to the mana nerfs (Which also affects her clear, cuz W into E costs a lot of mana), the nerf to her R so that its 3 minutes. And on top of this, shes incredibly hard to use compared to other champions... I mean honestly I'd rather just see a rework at this point than these nerfs. I guess Ill have to find another mid laner now... Damn. What a shame. And to think, it is only because of LCS and LCK and whatever other championships... Pisses me off.

>Even if the Azir "main" winrates were high, they deserve it

yeah no

I can totally understand that it is subjective, especially for a champion like Azir.  But there has to be champions like Taliyah, like Cassiopeia, like Gragas, like Nidalee, that bring more skill to the game.

"Gragas"

What? There are way better examples of champions that require skill to the game than Gragas.

Yes, Gragas, the champion who, when he was completely broken and could 1 shot any non-tank with just Q+R and was pick/ban, had a 34% winrate. 

Gragas, the champion that, no matter how strong of a showing he makes in competitive, never seems to become pick/ban in solo queue, despite having strong damage, sustain, tankiness, utility, disengage, pick potential, etc.

Gragas is a pretty simple champion, yes, but using him well requires a lot more skill than it looks like it would.

If you are gonna list Cassiopeia, Tallyiah, Azir and Nidalee in a list, you don't group them as the same difficulty as Gragas.

He is tanky so it's a very forgiving champion, his E has a very large hitbox, has damage reduction and heals to allow survivng in sticky situations, has decent mobility, his ult has a large effect radius, so even if you miss it by a bit it still does the job. It requires some macro knowledge, but what jungler doesn't?

I'd argue that Gragas is harder to make use of than a few of those, actually. 

Cass, Tal, Azir, and Nid are all very forgiving champs as well. 

__________

Tal's hitboxes are pretty large. Utilizing her ult well is what's difficult about her. 

Nid's only 'skill' is hitting Q. Its braindead after that, especially after they removed the R AA-reset. 

Azir is one of the safest champs in the game. Its getting kill pressure with him that's difficult now. Mechanically he takes getting used to;** its his utility that's hard to make good use of, not the damage/safety.** Most people use him for the damage because its so insanely safe overall. 

Cass isn't exactly hard, especially after the rework. She's got an extra tool, and E is no longer nearly as reliant on Q/W. She got easier than before, and she wasn't all that hard then either. 

Not to mention how itemization favors them all, outside of maybe Nid. 

_____

Its a long-shot to call any of that, outside of Azir's mechanical requirements, more difficult than Gragas, who has 4 significantly delayed abilities (outside of point-blank E), 3 of which are skillshots. 

I'm not downplaying how difficult it can be to utilize them; simply stating that Gragas is just as hard to utilize well, outside of optimal use of Azir's utility.

Azir's kit doesn't really fit the game in terms of balance.  It exist to such a point where anyone who has actually learned the champion isn't simply rewarded for being good but actually becomes problematic for the rest of the game and anyone they play against.  When he's strong Azir simply limits the game in a sense that you must either counterpick him or ban him all together against someone who knows how to play Azir. 

Also it really bothers me when someone says a champion takes no skill, all champions take skill even if its not mechanical skill. That's why there's a massive void difference between a diamond Garen and a bronze Garen.

I'd also like to add that 100 games can swing one way or the other. If you want true statistics, I think people should look at 500-1000 games to get a more accurate value.  100 games can invariably change, in my opinion.

um no?

She has incredible kiting potential. Her Q alone can farm an entire wave of minions due to the large missile hitboxes hitting multiple minions. It has the range of a goddamn fully charged Xerath Q while being 100% completely mobile like lucian's R, using it to kite anyone who gets close. Her mines cover the width of an ENTIRE lane, and that's no exaggeration. You literally have to walk through a FIELD of slow she sets on the ground to get to her if you're not someone like azir or LB who will cross the gap in the blink of an eye with their abilities, or morg/xerath who have ultra long skillshots, and that one ever annoying little pop-up skillshot that honestly doesn't really bother me that much, although it can pop her slow field's dash effect which it honestly shouldn't, and an ult that makes ganking and roaming very simple and makes impassable terrain in an instant.

She has the same issues as Azir, she has super safe poke, super safe kiting and disengage, and mobility with high ratios

All of this happened because of the vector change.

She was not supposed to be a combo champion, but non-Taliyah mains complained and now she is yet another combo champion.

The problem here is a fundamental flaw in Riot's champion design system. Taliyah, Yasuo, Aurelion Sol, Azir...all of them have high skill floors and high skill ceilings. They require significant investment of time to learn, so most people don't realm understand how they work. This creates the same winrate trend we're all familiar with: low early, low mid, sudden spike. You're left with a committed group who learned the champion and can use it effectively vs. a general public that doesn't know its mechanics. Riot nerfs the champ based off of the mains and LCS players and it's left in an unplayable state for everyone else. It's bad, sloppy design.

The reverse is essentially how you end up with Ekko: a brain dead champion with so low a skill floor that anybody can suddenly start using him any time a new OP build comes out for him. When Aurelion Sol was going to get needed for his high winrate on mains, you didn't see a sudden increase in his plaurate. Tank Ekko is discovered, though, and he was in every game.

This is the crux of the issue. Riot needs to stop releasing champions with too high or too low a skill requirement, because these champions end up requiring constant adjustments. The champs should be easy to learn and hard to master, to borrow the old cliche. I love Taliyah, but I recall predicting this exact turn of events when I discussed her with a friend. I'm sorry to see it happened, though. RIP, Taliyah.
